metadata.title: Nanomaterials Modified Cellulose Paper as a Platform for Biosensing Application

sections.text: and industry. Not only is paper highly abundant and portable, it is lightweight, disposable, easy-to-use, and can be rolled or folded into 3D configurations. More importantly, with unique porous bulk structure and rough and absorptive surface properties, the construction of nanomaterials functionalized cellulose was enabled on cellulose paper for point-of-care (POC) paper devices with reasonably good performance at low cost. In this review, latest advances in the modification of nanomaterials on paper cellulose were summed up. To begin with, attractive properties of paper based analytical devices were described. Then, fabricating methods in the functionalization of cellulose with diverse materials, including noble metal, bimetal, metal oxide, carbon nanomaterials, and molecular imprinting polymer nanoparticles, as well as their applications were introduced in detail. Eventually, current critical issues, challenges and future prospectives in exploring paper based analytical system based on nanomaterials modified cellulose were discussed. It is believed that more strategies will be developed to construct nanomaterials functionalized cellulose, paving the path for mass production of POC paper devices with satisfied performance possessed.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Paper has attracted increasing attention in recent years as an ideal platform for constructing portable miniature diagnostic devices, which is especially valuable for

developing countries, resource limited environments, and point-of-care settings. 1-5 Paper has a lot of intriguing features that renders this substrate advantageous for conducting chemical and biological analysis, such as passive transport of fluid through capillary wicking, 6, 7 good biocompatibility and biodegradability and so forth. Besides, paper-based devices are being increasingly utilized due to other following merits. (i) Paper is abundant and affordable. (ii) Paper substrates possess a porous structure, facilitating the immobilization of sensing materials and diffusion of analytes. 8 The surface of cellulose of paper can be modified with diverse functional groups to conjugate proteins, 9, 10 DNA, 11-14 and other molecules. 15-17 (iii) A large surface-to-volume ratio is offered, allowing for sufficient reagent storage. (iv) Paper can be easily patterned by traditional photolithography processes, 18 inkjet printing, 19 wax printing, 20 or screen printing methods for mass production 21 . (v) Paper-based models is feasibly foldable to form ramose or multilaminate microfluidic channels for multiplexing 22-24 and 3D-framing 25-27 with flexible fluidic control. (vi) Paper-related devices are disposable by an incinerator because of its combustibility. 28 (vii) Paper-based devices tend to transport and apply due to its thin, lightweight and flexible. Founded on such distinct merits, paper has been widely used in various fields. 29 For example, disposable paper devices can be applied in biomedicine, 10, 30, 31 environmental control, 32-34 and personal monitoring devices. 35, 36 Meanwhile, there are a variety of scientific and engineering barriers to the large-scale adoption of next-generation paper-based analytical devices that have stimulated tremendous research in this field. 15 Latest advances in microfluidic paper-based analytical devices (µPADs) extend its application inbiosensing field 37-39 via fluorescence, 40, 41 chemiluminescence, 42, 43 electrochemical, 12, 44 electrochemiluminescence, 45, 46 and photoelectrochemical 47, 48 and colorimetric methods. 49, 50

Microfluidic paper-based analytical devices are critical for identifying and measuring the quantity of analytes in a variety of environments that lack access to laboratory infrastructure. 51-53 So, one of the great challenges in science and engineering today is the development of simple, portable, affordable, yet highly sensitive and specific POC technologies for quantitative detection. Such capability will streamline healthcare and improve clinical outcomes, substantially improving the standard of living. 39, 52, 54, 55 Paper has emerged as a cheap, universal, and scalable platform for POC assays, with µPADs as a central format. 1, 2, 56-59 The functionalization of cellulose materials has the potential to extend the functionality and application field of µPADs in the development of new sensing devices. 60, 61 The integration of nanomaterials into paper evidently enhances detection capabilities. 13 In the past few years, we have witnessed the integration of µPADs with functional nanomaterials such as noble metal, bimetal, metal oxide, carbon nanomaterial, and molecular imprinting polymers (Fig.1). 62, 63 All of them possessed distinctive properties, improving the performance of µPADs and broadening its application fields significantly (Table 1). 64

The nanoscale endows materials with remarkable changes in properties, resulting in strengthened performance and even distinctive functionalities. 89-92 To enhance the performance of µPADs and meet specific requirements during applications, the surface of cellulose of µPADs may be modified with nanomaterials, which has been confirmed to be an effective strategy. 93, 94 A large variety of functional and well-designed architectures have been successfully fabricated via employing specific strategies. 80, 95, 96 These composites demonstrated particular optical, electronical, physical, chemical, or biological properties compared with free nanomaterial counterparts and have vast potential for various applications. 60 Paper substrates hold a porous structure which facilitate the immobilization of sensing materials and diffusion of analytes. 97 Nanomaterials are mainly used to construct sensing interface in µPADs, serving as static sensing elements. Leveraging nanomaterials for active transport in paper would enable advanced control of target analytes, extending the current molecular diagnostic capabilities of paper-based devices. 13 In this article, we summarized the common stategies for cellulose functionalization with nanomaterials (Table 2) and their applications in biosensors based on vast research results available.

sections.heading: 2. Modification of noble metal nanomaterials on paper cellulose
sections.text:
To improve the performance of µ-PADs, and ensure sufficient efficiency and sensitivity of the reactions in the application of µ-PADs, a good few noble metal naomaterials are used to modify the cellulose. Noble metal nanomaterials hold superiorly optical, electrochemical and chemical properties. Consequently, noble metal nanomaterials modified cellulose of µ-PADs are widely used in the fields of optics and electrochemical sensors. 111-113 In addition, the agglomeration of noble metal nanomaterials may evidently reduce their efficiency in solution. Noble nanomaterials are immobilized on the surface of cellulose as a scaffold to enhance the conductivity and biocompatibility. As an ideal scaffold, a large surface area, and strong interaction with noble metal nanomaterials are essential. Adopting ample cellulose as a scaffold for metals can be a feasible means to sustain their high activities. Currently, the strategies of modifying celluloses with noble metal nanomaterials are subjected by postimmobilization as well as the in-situ growth on cellulose substrates. For postimmobilization method, high dispersity and uniformity of noble metal nanomaterials are vital. Surface pretreatment is usually employed to introduce bonds between noble metals and substrates. 114 In situ growth approach is greatly influence by various factors that shall be precisely controlled, including the

To yield anchoring sites for the noble metal precursor growth and control the structure of the produced noble metal nanoparticles, certain chemical promoters or surfactants are usually used simutaneously. 60
Attention have been paid to enhance the conductivity and the immobilization of bio-recognition substance on cellulose for signal amplification of paper-based assays. Au NPs have appealed to much attention in the immobilization of cellulose due to its distinctive physical and chemical properties, such as easily controllable size distribution, superior conductivity, long-term stability, and biocompatibility 99, 115 . In view of the above merits, our group reported that Au nanoparticles could grow on the surface of cellulose in the form of an interconnected Au NPs layer. Au nanoparticles modified cellulose was served as PWE on a compatibly designed µ-PADs to enhance the conductivity of the paper. In the process, the suspension of Au seeds was firstly prepared by using NaBH4 as reductant and stabilized with sodium citrate, the Au NPs layer further grew on the surface of Au NP seeded cellulose in growth aqueous solution of phosphate buffer saline (PBS) containing HAuCl4, cetyltrimethylammonium chloride and H2O2. As shown in Fig. 2, there was no apparent structure and surface difference between bare and Au NPs seeded cellulose due to the small particle size of Au seeds. With the increment of reaction time, Au seeds were rapidly enlarged by incubating in the growth solution under self-catalytic reduction mechanism. Finally, a continuous and dense conducting Au NPs layer was obtained on the cellulose surfaces after 10 min of growth. Due to the high specific surface area and porous structure of paper, the resulting Au NPs layer on the cellulose possessed higher effective surface area. Correspondingly, the porous Au-PWE for immobilizing bio-recognition molecules revealed enhanced sensitivity than that of the bare one (unmodified PWE). 44, 65, 116 In terms of simplicity and cost efficiency, inkjet printing is very competitive over other existing methods. Hu et al. reported a simple approach to produce batches of nanoporous gold electrode arrays on cellulose membranes by inkjet printing. 117 Such approach can fabricate hundreds of self-designed gold arrays on cellulose membranes within several hours. The resulting paper-based gold electrode arrays had several unique properties as thin-film sensor platforms, including good conductivity, excellent flexibility, high integration, and low cost. The present work thus demonstrates the promising applications of paper-based porous electrode arrays in electrochemical gas sensing.

On the basis of the same mechanism, our group also fabricated Ag NPs on the surface of cellulose of µ-PADs. 101 Porous Ag NPs were achieved by adjusting the growth of Ag NPs layer from Ag seeds to Ag NPs on the surface of cellulose in the paper, which further immobilized capture antibodies through chemical absorption between Ag NPs and −NH2 groups of capture antibody (Fig. 3). Thanks to the high specific surface area and porous structure of paper and the good conductivity of porous Ag NPs, the sensitivity of as-designed µ-PADs were remarkably improved.

Ag NPs-modified paper cellulose can be served as a bioactive substrate for surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) detection as well. Srikanth and co-workers reported SERS paper substrates impregnated with gold nanorods by dip coating. 62, 119, 120 Yu reported highly sensitive SERS substrate on paper by inkjet printing using a cheap inkjet printer. 121, 122 The functional sensing regions were hydrophobic. Subsequently, the as-prepared Ag NPs were printed onto this regions to form sensing arrays. The hydrophobic surface detered the aqueous sample from diffusing all over the paper and thus concentrated the analyte within the sensing region. The as-proposed paper-based SERS substrates with vitally low cost and simplicity of fabrication may facilitate their applicaiton in routine lab as well as POC. A technology into the real world should meet the demand of low cost and easy operation. Polavarapu et al. presented a “pen-on paper” (POP) approach for making SERS substrates. 123 As shown in Fig. 4 (a, e, g), Au NPs and Au nanorods were uniform in dimension, whereas Ag NPs showed polydispersity including Ag nanorods. The three different inks were deposited on cellulose with fountain pens filled the corresponding nanoparticles. The morphology of the SERS substrate could be easily controlled, which were presented in Fig.4 using three different inks. It was showed that the nanoparticles were compactly packed and adsorbed onto the surface of cellulose, so they were anticipated to produce intense SERS signals. Via this approach, no professional training was required to fabricate nanomaterials-modified cellulose for SERS arrays on paper using an ordinary fountain pen filled with inks comprising metal nanomaterials of arbitrary shape and size.

Recently, Nishikata et al. investigated the modification of Pd NPs on filter paper based on electrostatic interactions. 124 Zheng et al. reported that a novel catalytic system based on Pd NPs loaded on cellulose was established with high efficiency and recyclability. Paper as scaffold for Pd NPs-based catalysts was explored for diverse chemical reactions. The main superiority of the resulting catalytic material were simplified handling and easy recovery. The catalyst was prepared through the templated assembly of oleylamine-stabilized Pd nanoparticls on cellulose filter paper. 125 Furthermore, Pt NPs were chosen as a biocompatible nanomaterial due to its superior conductivity, strong absorption ability, bioactivity and stability of immobiling biomolecules. 126-128 Yu group reported the fabrication of Pt nanoparticles modified cellulose. 67 Firstly, Pt seeds solution was dropped onto the bare PWE and equilibrated at ambient temperature for 1 h. Then, an interconnected Pt nanoparticls layer was grown on the cellulose through Pt seeds growth strategy in the sample zone of PWE. Using the as-prepared Pt-PWE as sensing platform, in situ and real-time determination of H2O2 was successfully achieved by highly affinitive binding with aptamers for capturing SK-BR-3 cancer cells (Fig. 5). 68

sections.heading: 3. Modification of bimetal nanomaterials on paper cellulose
sections.text:
Bimetal nanoparticles including alloy and core−shell nanoparticles, have gained tremendous attention due to their strikingly electronic, optical, magnetic and catalytic properties in comparison with their monometallic counterparts. They have been widely applied in the field of catalysis, sensors, and surface-enhanced Raman scattering. 129-132 As one of the most abundant materials and truly ubiquitous in modern society, cellulose is an ideal subatrate for the assembly and immobilization of bimetal nanoparticles, which could not only offer better stability and easier recyclability of bimental nanoparticles, but also increase their performance, thus making the application of bimetal nanoparticles modified cellulose popular in various fields.

Recently, our group developed a facile methods to prepare Au@Pt NPs modified cellulose (Fig. 6 I). Au@Pt NPs as catalysts showed a dramatically higher reaction rate compared to pure Au and Pt NPs. The catalytic activity depended on the chemical composition of bimetal nanoparticles, which demonstrated a strong synergistic effect between Au and Pt. 78, 133 The fabrication of Au@Pt nanoparticles was as follow. Au seed solution was firstly dropped into specific zone of paper device. The paper was equilibrated for 2 h, followed by washing with Milli-Q water. Freshly prepared growth aqueous solution of PBS containing HAuCl4 and H2PtCl6 was dropped into the Au seeded PWE. Controlling the ratio of HAuCl4 and H2PtCl6, Au@Pt nanoparticles with different ratio could be obtained. Subsequently, the resulting Au@Pt-PWE was washed with Milli-Q water thoroughly, and dried at room temperature. An interconnected Au@Pt nanoparticles layer was in-situ grown on the surfaces of cellulose to build conductivity-enhaned PWE on an origami photoelectrochemical device (Fig. 6 II), which was utilized for the real-time visual determination of H2S released from multiple cancer cells for the first time. 72 Ge et al. also reported that the zinc oxide nanorods (ZNRs) were grown on Au@Pt nanoparticles modified PWE via in situ growth method. The ZNRs/Au@Pt-PWE resulted in an enhanced excitation and photo-to-electric conversion efficiency. As a consequence, amplified photocurrent signals were achieved. Eventually, the invented immunodevice was successfully applied for the monitoring of carcinoembryonic antigen and α-fetoprotein (Fig. 6 III).
Their properties of bimetal nanomaterials are not only depended on size and shape, but also on composition and structure. 134, 135 A special attention has been attracted on the preparation of bimetallic nanoparticles with highly dendritic/porous structures. Owing to their high surface area and rich surface atoms, dendritic/porous nanostructures are favorable to high catalytic performance. A porous Au@Pd nanoparticles were synthesized by the in-situ growth strategy. Utilizing the cellulose as a scaffold, not only conductivity-enhanced PWE were obtained, but also the

as-prepared bimetallic nanoparticles exhibited excellent peroxidases-like catalytic activity. (Fig. 7I). The fabrication of Au@Pd-PWE was described as follows: Firstly, Au seed solution was dropped into the PWE. Then the paper-based device was equilibrated at room temperature for 1 h. After rinsing with water thoroughly to eliminate unbound Au seeds, the Au seeded PWE was immersed into the growth solution containing HAuCl4 and H2PdCl4. Ascorbic acid solution was then added quickly under gentle shaking. Finally, the resulting Au@Pd-PWE was rinsed with water thoroughly and dried at ambient temperature. 48, 73 Utilizing as-prepared bimetallic nanomaterial to construct the sensing platform (Fig. 7 II), not only the immobilization of antibodies increased, but also the detection response was amplified ascribe to the catalase-like catalytic activity of dendritic Au@Pd NPs . The sensitivity of sensing platform with Au@Pd–PWE was much higher than that of a bare one (unmodified PWE) or monometallic counterparts because of the high sepcific surface area, the porous structure as well as the high conductivity of Au@Pd NPs. In addition, Au@Pd NPs demonstrated superior catalytic activity and electron transfer process. To evaluate the reliability of the proposed Au@Pd NPs modified cellulose, CEA in human serum samples were used for the practical assay. Interestingly, the designed bimetallic NPs based sensing platform could be easily extended for monitoring other targets and has the potential for reliable diagnosis of cancer and other diseases.

sections.heading: 4. Modification of metal oxide nanomaterials on paper cellulose
sections.text:
The application of metal oxide prevails in various fields. Utilizing metal oxide nanoparticles to modify cellulose, extends the application of paper-based analytical device. Metal oxides coated cellulose can not only exhibit better stability and easier recyclability but also enhance the performance of paper analytical device. As an ideal scaffold, cellulose holds rich surface OH groups and intrinsic porous nanostructure. Cellulose-metal oxide composites combine the processability of cellulose and the superior performances of metal oxide materials. To fabricate cellulose-metal oxide composites, it is critical that the surface of the cellulose substrate is lined with inorganic ions. So far, many researchers have been dedicated to fabricating cellulose-metal oxide composites with differed metal oxides, including TiO2, 136 ZnO, 137 Fe3O4, 138 CuO, 139 ZnO-SiO2, 140 . Similar to many other composites, homogeneous dispersion of metal oxide nanoparticles over the cellulose is great challenge owning to the aggregation of metal oxide nanomaterials in synthesis process, which severely affect the performances of obtained composites. To address this issue, various strategies have been exploited to fabricate metal oxide nanoparticles modified cellulose with high dispersity. Metal oxides are immobilized on cellulose scaffold generally in two ways. One is a two-step process. To manipulate the nanoparticle size and morphology of metal oxide over cellulose, it is better to prepare monodisperse nanoparticles first and assemble these nanoparticles onto cellulose materials subsequently. The other is in situ growth that can guarantee strong cellulose−metal oxide interaction in cellulose−metal oxide composites. This method usually demands a high temperature and high-pressure environment for nanoparticle nucleation and growth on cellulose.
The immobilization of metal oxide nanoparticles onto a cellulose substrate has drawn widely interest academically and industrially. These composites showed some distinguished performance, such as antibacterial, 141-143 , photocatalysis 144-146 , and sensor 142, 147, 148
. For instance, El-Naggar et al. reported that TiO2 nanoparticles was
in-situ deposited onto cellulose without severely destroying the cellulose. 149 Urea nitrate was firstly used as a peptizing agent to transform titanium hydroxide to TiO2 nanoparticles. It was found that the TiO2 nanoparticles coated on cellulose were composed of aggregated particles with an average size of less than 50 nm. Interestingly, TiO2 NPs-coated cellulose showed a bacterial reduction of more than

These treated cellulose executed well in bacterial reduction and ultraviolet visible protection regardless of washing. 149 Gullapalli et al. prepared zinc oxide nanostructures embedded in a stable matrix of paper (cellulose) by a solvothermal method for sensing strain under both static and dynamic loading. 150 Here, the nanostructured ZnO was crystallized in the matrix by immersing a seed layer coated paper substrate in aqueous solution of a precursor and a solvent maintained at low temperature, generally less than 100 °C. 93 To evaluate the strain sensing capabilities of ZnO paper, ZnO paper was attached to a brass beam, and its response to a change in strain was measured by monitoring the output current. ZnO paper strain sensor showed a shift in current output at different strain levels. Metal oxide nanoparticles was grown only on the paper fibers exposed on the surface of the paper, which served primarily as an inert substrate to sustain the growth of active nanostructures.
Zhang et al. prepared ZnO nanorods immobilized paper substrates by pulsed laser deposition (PLD) method for the construction of paper-based ZnO nanorods inorganic–organic heterostructured light-emitting diode (LED) (Fig. 8 I). Silver electrode was firstly screen-printed on a bare paper (unmodified paper) to offer a smooth surface for subsequent growth of ZnO NRs and served as a back contact before PLD was carried out. Subsequently, it was polished until the surface changed into smooth and shiny. Then it was washed several times by milli-Q water and dried, the cellulose of paper were deposited with a ~100 nm thick ZnO seed layer that provided nucleation sites for the growth of ZnO nanorods. 77 As a proof-of-concept, the proposed LED was used as an excitation light source to construct an advanced multiplexed PEC immunosensor array (Fig. 8 II), and superior performances were gained in real application. ZnO NRs modified paper substrate was very significant in many practical applications for flexible/foldable and disposable electronic devices. Furthermore, the convergence of LED technology and biotechnology opens up a new avenue for the development of simple, inexpensive, portable, and easy-to-use point-of-care testing platforms for public health, environmental monitoring in developing countries, resource-limited and remote regions with limited facilities.

Cellulosic paper has been demonstrated to have high protein capacity, which could increase detection signal and improve assay sensitivity. However, it is a rather nonreactive material for direct chemical coupling as well. In order to develop a potent method for controlled conjugation cellulose and proteins, Bodelo´n et al. fabricated a hybrid scaffold based on the adsorption and in situ self-assembly of surface-oxidized nickle nanoparticles on the cellulose of paper, which acted as “docking sites” for the selective immobilization of proteins containing polyhistidine tags (His-tag) (Fig. 9). The interaction between the nickel substrate and the His-tagged protein G is noticeably resilient toward chemicals at concentrations that quickly disrupt standard Ni-NTA and Ni-IDA complexes. Excitingly, such devised system is a robust attachment. The versatility and biocompatibility of the oxide nickel substrate were further demonstrated by enzymatic reactions. 64

The composites containing metal oxides and other nanomaterials normally present more superior performance compared with those containing single metal oxide. 151, 152 For example, Sun et al. reported that ZnO nanoflakes (ZNF) were electrodeposited onto gold modified paper electrode, and then functionalized with CuS by hydrothermal and ion exchange method. The recombination process of electron–hole pairs in CuS was hindered due to the match of energy levels between ZnO and CuS. In addition, due to ZNF possessing high surface area, it provided much more multidimensional spaces for loading CuS, which enhanced visible light absorption. In virtue of the fast electron transfer from CuS to ZNF and then to Au paper electrode, the sensor exhibited high PEC performance. 104 Lan et al. fabricated a photoelectrochemical immunosensor with a microfluidic paper-based analytical devices using different sizes of CdTe quantum dots sensitized flower-like 3D ZnO superstructures as photoactive materials (Fig. 10), which could not only adequately utilize light luminous energy but also effectively promoted charge separation and consequently enhanced the photocurrent conversion efficiency due to the cascade band-edge levels by coupling different band gap semiconductor quantum dots as sensitizers. 47

sections.heading: 5. Modification of carbon nanomaterials on paper cellulose
sections.text:
In recent years, various carbon nanomaterials (CNMs), including 0D, 1D and 2D, such as fullerenes, CNTs, GO and rGO have attracted dramatic attention. Featured with unique properties, such as large specific surface area, high intrinsic carrier mobility, electrical conductivity, environment stability as well as potential for low-cost production, the CNMs have already substantiated its promising in applications in nanoelectronics, energy storage devices, capacitors, microelectrodes and sensors devices. 153 These CNMs supported on cellulose is incorporated with µ PADs, building up a series of biosensors that quantitatively and selectively detect biomolecules. 153
The performance of paper-based electronic devices depends on conductive properties of the structures fabricated on the paper, which completely relies on the density and the connectivity of the conducting material. 5, 20 Hence, with excellent conductivity, multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) was deposited directly onto cellulose by dip coating to prepare conductive MWNT–cellulose. The as-prepared MWNT– cellulose bring more benefits as follows. (I) The fabrication process is simple and scalable; (II) It is more potent in creating conductive CNT-to-CNT junction networks, resulting in noticeably low CNT loadings compared to the previously reported percolation threshold values for composites; (III) The features of cellulose-based materials could be maintained; (IV)The CNTs coated on the surface of cellulose can encounter directly and quickly with chemicals, which enhances the sensitivity distinctly. Yun et al. developed a carbon nanotube−cellulose composite paper. MWNTs were imported into paper as a conducting material through covalent bonding between cellulose and MWNTs. A transistor was prepared on this paper without the existence of any semiconducting or insulating layer. To be surprised, the on/off ratio was proved to mainly rely on the content of MWNTs in the paper. 154 Our group also reported that CNTs was modified cellulose on the PWE of paper device through sequential assembling. Positively charged Poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride)-functionalized CNTs (PDDA− CNTs) and negatively charged CdS NPs was assembled on the interwoven cellulose. 108 The photocurrent generated by CdS/PWE

Therefore, CNTs which bridged the CdS NPs to the screen-printed carbon working electrode may promote the photocurrent generation by trapping the conduction-band electrons. The conductive CNTs-modified interwoven cellulose provides efficient and fast electron-transfer paths for the conduction-band electrons to the PWE.
Graphene is an exciting material because of its one atom-thick 2D structure which makes it easily deformed in the direction normal perpendicular to its surface, providing good mechanical flexibility. 153 It has a large theoretical specific surface area, high intrinsic mobility, high Young’s modulus and thermal conductivity, and its optical transmittance and good electrical conductivity merit attention for applications such as transparent conductive electrodes, among many other potential applications. 155 The inherent mechanical and electronic properties of graphene make it charming material for the applications in bioanalysis and other devices related to sensor such as µ PADs.
GO and gold nanowires (GNWs) composites were prepared through noncovalent absorption. The resulting GNWs/GO hybrids combining the advantages of graphene and GNWs were used as new electrode material to construct an ultrasensitive immunosensor through cellulose as a scaffold. Li et al. reported that working electrode of 3D-µPAD was fabricated through chitosan coating and GNWs/GO modifying as shown in Fig. 11 I. 82 CuS/GO composites were prepared using GO as the starting material, the oxygen containing groups in GO controlled the decoration of CuS nanoparticles without aggregation. The composites of ultrathin gold nanowire and graphene with high water solubility, extraordinary biological and electrical properties were prepared in situ solution phase to establish an electrochemical sensor. The CuS/GO nanocomposites-based sensor showed high sensitivity, stability, and fast amperometric response toward the electro-oxidation of H2O2. Such established sensor was successfully applied to the detection of AFP in real serum samples from both healthy people and cancer patients, and the results were well consistent with a commercial electrochemiluminescence method, which demonstrated the potential application of nanocomposites in developing highly sensitive, environmental friendly, and cost-effective electrochemical biosensors. Sun et al. fabricated the rGO modified cellulose of paper working electrode via in-situ hydrothermal reduction of GO. Next,

In order to improve the performance of the sensor based on paper analytical device, Au NPs and flower-like reduced graphene oxide (FrGO) was used to modify the cellulose (Fig. 12) by Yu’s group. Au NPs layer was grown on the surfaces of cellulose positioned at the hydrophilic zone of the paper to build Au-PWE. Prior to modify the FrGO on the cellulose of the analytical device, flower-like ZnO (FZnO) template was fabricated firstly. Then the Au-PWE was soaked into the above mixed solution. The resulting FZnO/Au-PWE was prepared, followed by repeatedly washing with ethanol and water. Finally, the FZnO/Au-PWE was immersed in GO solution and electrochemically reduced at a constant potential. After the electroreduction process, the rGO-FZnO/Au-PWE was treated with hydrochloric acid to remove the ZnO template. The resulting FrGO/Au modified cellulose was successfully prepared and utilized as working electrode. Such proposed biosensor showed high sensitivity, good stability, acceptable reproducibility in Pb 2+ detection attributing to the electron transfer acceleration of Au/FrGO/Au-PWE. This method could be expanded readily for detecting other metal ions and help monitoring public and environmental safety. 80 Besides the template sacrifice approach, graphene modified the cellulose of paper was

sections.heading: 6. Modification of molecular imprinted polymer on paper cellulose
sections.text:
In spite that, the current analytical methods based on µ-PADs showed remarkable sensitivity and selectivity, most of them depended almost completely on sophisticated biological receptors, such as antibodies, 159-161 DNA 162-164 or aptamer 165-167 as biochemical recognition elements. These bio-molecules may be subjected to limitations because of their biological denaturation. Molecular imprinting polymer (MIP) as a well-known and widely used tool to produce synthetic biomimetic receptors for target molecules, providing an ideal substitute. 168-170 Hence, rapid growth of interest was observed in the fabrication and development of MIP. MIP was produced by cross-linking monomers in the presence of a template molecule (target molecules). The resulting cavities reproduced the size and shape even if the template was removed, and the resulting material could specifically recognize and bind the target. Featured with many merits including specific recognition, superior physical

Our group introduced molecular imprinting technique into µ-PADs. 85 MIP was coated the surface of AuNPs modified cellulose through electropolymerization of functional monomer. MIP layer was prepared toward acetate buffer solution containing template (D-glutamic acid) and monomer (o-PD) in Au-PWE at room temperature (Fig. 13). Due to the porous morphology of the paper as well as the high specific surface area and conductivity of the resulting Au NPs layer on the cellulose, the effective surface area and the sensitivity of the Au-PWE was enhanced remarkably. The molecular recognition occured between D-glutamic acid and the binding cavities in MIP layer, which hindered the electron transfer of the [Fe(CN)6] 3-/4- redox reaction to the Au-PWE. The peak current decreased with the increase of D-glutamic concentration. Based on MIP technique and the principle of origami, a microfluidic MIP-based electro-analytical origami device (µ -MEOD) was established for the detection of D-glutamic acid. This µ-MEOD exhibited a novel platform for high selectivity, high-sensitivity, high-throughput, high specific, and multiplex assay as well as point-of-care diagnosis in public health as well as, environmental monitoring. Our group also reported that a layer of polypyrrole was grafted on the ZnO/Au-PWE surface by simple electropolymerization method. 88 After the template molecule was removed from the matrix of MIPs, the recognition sites of MIPs were fabricated, which could specifically recognize and bind pentachlorophenol. The proposed PEC sensor exhibited a short absorption time, high selectivity, good precision, acceptable stability and reproducibility, and could be used for the detection of pentachlorophenol in real samples.

Meanwhile, our group established a molecularly imprinted polymer-grafted paper-based multi-disk micro-disk plate (PMIP-MMP) for the detection of pesticide (Fig. 14). 86 MIP-grafted paper disks were fabricated by a facile in-situ polymerization of MIP layer on the surface of cellulose. Before the in-situ polymerization of MIP, C=C groups was introduce onto the surface of cellulose using a silane-coupling technique. After silanization of the surfaces of cellulose, in-situ polymerization of the MIPs layer on the surface of cellulose was performed. Then, binding sites on the MIP surface were created through eluting the template molecule. Each MIP-grafted paper disk on the P-MIP-MMP was independently assayed, and the structure of the plate promoted simultaneous assay of multiplex samples. An indirect competitive assay format, based on the competition between free analyte and immobilized analyte in the grafted MIP layer, was used to quantify the analyte in the sample. 97 Herein, the proposed paper-based MIP-grafted multi-disk micro-disk plate was used to detect 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid as a proof-of-concept analyte. 86 This approach afforded a potent protocol for simple, low-cost, rapid, and high-throughput detection of pesticides in real samples with satisfactory results in the area of food inspection, and environmental monitoring and so on.

Conjugated polymers such as polythiophenes, polypyrroles, polyanilines, poly(p-phenylenevinylene), and their derivatives have been normally employed in photovoltaic devices as antenna layers for the photovoltaic conversion of solar energy because of their high absorption coefficients in the visible light region, high mobility of charge carriers, and excellent stability. These polymers were used to modify the cellulose, which increased the properties of paper device. Zhang et al. reported a flexible fully-integrated self-powered system on the paper, 171 in which electrode material as well as conducting interconnections, p-toluenesulfonic acid (p-TSA) doped polypyrrole embedded in-between the cellulose fibers (p-TSA-PPy/cellulose) were obtained by combining in-situ chemical oxidative polymerization with paper microfluidic technique. In such unique integrated configuration, the utilization of p-TSA-PPy/cellulose network not only dramatically enhanced the horizontal electrical conductivity, but also conquered the issue of vertical electroconductivity, allowing for the top-channel-bottom conductive interconnections. As a proof-of-concept, an all-paper microfluidic analytical platform that integrated paper based electrochemiluminescence strategy and proposed power paper was constructed with comparable performance obtained. This work greatly improves the understandings of all-paper-based self-powered systems, and presents the significant potential applications of paper-based flexible electronics. Li et al. reported that a sensitive microfluidic origami electrochemical immunodevice was established based on polyaniline- Au NPs modified paper working electrode (PANI/Au-PWE) as sensor platform and different redox substrates as tracers. 110 PANI fibers with a diameter of about 150 nm were tangledand twisted with each other, forming uniform and porous net-works on Au-PWE, which further increased effective surface area and enhanced electron transfer for sensitive electrochemical response.Due to the electropolymerization of aniline in an Au-PWE, the effective surface area of the PANI/Au-PWE could remarkably enhanced the sensitivity. A molecular imprinting polymer with conductivity was introduced into microfluidic paper-based analytical devices through electropolymerization of molecular imprinted polyaniline (MPANI) in a novel Au nanoparticles (Au NPs)-modified paper working electrode (Au-PWE) . 87 Under visible light irradiation, MPANI could generate the photoelectric transition from the highest occupied molecular orbital to the lowest unoccupied

Simultaneously, it is believed that a positively charged hole of MPANI that took part in the oxidation process was consumed by ascorbic acid to promote the amplification of photocurrent response. Polyterthiophene (pTTh) , a photoresponsive conducting polymer, showed superior outstanding optical properties and prominent environmental stability.Wu et al. reported that a paper-based analytical devices was built up for sensitive detection of the carbohydrate antigen 15-3 (CA15-3) through combining visible-light-enhanced biofuel cells and electrochemical immunosensor. pTTh served as catalyst in cathode for the reduction of oxygen upon illumination by visible light. The exceptional properties of pTTh made a potential alternative catalyst to trigger a cathodic reaction.
Conclusions and perspectives In conclusion, the paper device is becoming popular because of its low-cost and porous nature. Paper has tremendous potential for disposable point-of-care devices. So far, many fabrication techniques were established to construct conducting structures for biosensing devices. These techniques could be carried out in ordinary lab. To construct conducting structures, cellulose was served as a versatile scaffold for self-assembly toward advanced devices. Cellulose could be functionalized with metal, bimetallic, metal oxide, carbon and molecular imprinting polymer, which expanded the application of paper devices. A new composites with cellulose as the scaffold would arouse fascinating technologies and interesting applications. Nevertheless, many challenges still exist in the fabrication and application of cellulose composites materials.
At present, the cellulose composites materials of paper-based sensing devices reported mainly work very well in laboratory scale, yet when it comes to the reproducibility and repeatability, the performance of these devices do not match with those of commercial devices. Fine tuning of the formation and composition of these composites is vital to enhance their performance. The influence of different composite nanomaterials on the sensing devices needs to be investigated, which is essential to bring the paper-based sensing devices closer to market. It might require a concentrated effort of researchers in the cellulose modification of paper industry, materials, bioscience, and electrical engineering to transform the prototypes into commercial products.

The pulp and paper industry uses a lot of fibers from different sources to manufacture paper with different quality. However, most of the paper-based sensing devices are fabricated with Whatman filter paper or commercial printing papers. The effect of paper quality on device performance has not been determined. It is essential to investigate the effect of paper type on sensor performance, since the performances of paper, are dramantically influenced by the type of fibers. Also, most of the reports published are dedicated to developing scalable fabrication techniques and demonstrating novel applications of the paper-based devices. However, comprehensive mathematical modeling of the paper-based devices has not been undertaken yet, even the modeling of the electrical, ionic, and fluidic characteristics of paper could provide solutions to many of the problems associated with paper-based devices.
By combining structured paper cellulose with nanomaterials, versatile low-cost and easy-to-use paper fluidic testing systems can be generated for a wide range of analytical tasks. The paper devices are perfectly fit for operation outdoor and independent of high-tech laboratories. While numerous attention has been placed on the potential for improved clinical diagnostics, and expanded many other areas fields. Especially, the potential application of µPADs for large epidemiology studies is exciting, because traditional detection exists the cost and speed limiting factor. In a similar fashion, the low cost and ease of use may open the door to widespread analytical measurements which come true the self-monitoring of anyone, anytime and anywhere. However, the function of paper device is simple. Great efforts should be devoted to the integration of multi-function, miniaturization and intelligentization with higher sensitivity and selectivity. It is anticipanted that µPADs can evidently reduce the cost and realize remote point-of-care testing.

metadata.abstractText: Recently, paper substrates attract tremendous interest from both academia and industry. Not only is paper highly abundant and portable, it is lightweight, disposable, easy-to-use, and can be rolled or folded into 3D configurations. More importantly, with unique porous bulk structure and rough and absorptive surface properties, the construction of nanomaterials functionalized cellulose was enabled on cellulose paper for point-of-care (POC) paper devices with reasonably good performance at low cost. In this review, latest advances in the modification of nanomaterials on paper cellulose were summed up. To begin with, attractive properties of paper based analytical devices were described. Then, fabricating methods in the functionalization of cellulose with diverse materials, including noble metal, bimetal, metal oxide, carbon nanomaterials, and molecular imprinting polymer nanoparticles, as well as their applications were introduced in detail. Eventually, current critical issues, challenges and future prospectives in exploring paper based analytical system based on nanomaterials modified cellulose were discussed. It is believed that more strategies will be developed to construct nanomaterials functionalized cellulose, paving the path for mass production of POC paper devices with satisfied performance possessed.
